title: Who is a museum for? Artwork labels at the Burrell Collection
content: Nestling on the side of a small forest, with wide glass walls offering a balance and art, the refurbished Burrell Collection in Glasgow is one of the finest pieces of museum architecture in the United Kingdom. Its recent refurbishment allowed the museum not just to update the building but rethink the display, and how to […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: How many objects in Antwerp’s City Museum?
content: 610,000 objects according to the entrance to its public depot. The nine-storey building for MAS (Antwerp’s city museum; MAS stands for Museum aan de Stroom) features an open archive on the second floor. The archive is, in parts, well documented; extended texts and core information about highlighted objects in display cases. In other parts, behind […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Universal Tounge
content: “With the help of an international team of 52 researchers, Kruithof collected 8,800 videos from social media—totaling 250 hours of footage and featuring 1,000 dance styles from all 196 countries in the world. This material was edited into a four-hour dynamic dance video installation, shown across eight screens displaying a total of 32 hours of […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: The Bazball Revolution: Why the Stokes Era is Still a Win for English Cricket
content: For the English cricket fan, the recent Ashes tour of Australia might feel like a cold splash of reality. Losing 3-0 and surrendering the urn in just eleven days of active cricket is a bitter pill to swallow. In the wake of such a definitive defeat, it is easy to let the “I told you […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Imagining lost artworks with AI
content: Museums, unsurprisingly, defend the authenticity of the objects in their collections But the Met in New York is using AI to imagine the great quantity of works that have been lost to time, “imagining a third thing between two known things.” Most artworks have been destroyed, lost, forgotten (often long before they could even be […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Jonathan Jones sticks the knife in to Tate …
content: … but he’s als sticking in the knife into something fleshier. Museums have an odd pedigree. Ranging from Old Masters museums: stuffy, conservative, over-educated, elitist, quietly sustained by networks of the established rich – to contemporary art spaces: cutting-edge, avant-garde, desperately trying to create new discourses about today’s society. Even though Tate (Modern) is for […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: On suffering social media in hospitals
content: Ashley d’Aquino, a therapeutic radiographer in London, said a colleague had agreed to take photographs for a patient, “but when the patient handed over her phone the member of staff saw that the patient had also been covertly recording her, to publish on her cancer blog.” From The Guardian, 17 June 2025
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Jim Crace and the autobiographical self expression.
content: Jim Crace comments on how far he is from drawing of romantic notions of the tormented self. Who’d want to read my autobiography? Contented childhood, never beaten by my father, never heard my parents swear or argue. One happy marriage that has lasted thirty years. Children who are talented and charming, good health, no debts […]
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Five Takeaways from the 2025 Public Spaces conference
content: Last week I attended the 2025 Public Spaces conference, in the funky Pakhuis De Zwijger Amsterdam. It was a popular and crammed event – hundreds of enthusiastic attendees committed to designing a version of the Internet based on public values. Here are five takeaways from the event.
creator: Alastair Dunning

title: Refashioning architectural spaces
content: The Dutch are great at refashioning architectural spaces that have outlived their primary use. Here is the Vandervelde bookshop in Zwolle – converted from a 16th-century Dominican church
creator: Alastair Dunning
